Insights 

#  2024 Election Insights 

Throughout election season, we’ll be tracking the issues that matter to voters and addressing investor concerns about what the results may mean. 

![Capitol building](/content/dam/invesco/us/en/images/landing-pages/LNDG-HRO-1-2024-election-insights.jpg)

### Markets don’t choose sides

Despite investor concerns, presidential elections haven’t historically affected markets or the economy, no matter which party wins.[1](#1)

### Stay fully invested

Staying invested during both Democratic and Republican administrations yielded better results than investing only during a single party’s rule.[1](#1)

### Policy over politics

Monetary policy has had a greater market impact than party politics. Presidents have been either helped or hurt by Federal Reserve actions.[1](#1)

##  The view from Washington 

There’s been no shortage of twists and turns in this historically turbulent election. Global Head of Public Policy [Andy Blocker](/us/en/our-people/andy-blocker.html) and his team offers their latest insights into the race for the White House and what investors need to know.

![View of white house](/content/dam/invesco/us/en/images/insights/ARTCL-HRO-trump-win-policies-market-economy.jpg)

###  What Trump's win may mean for the markets and economy

Based on pledges made on the campaign trail, here are five key things we’ll be watching for from President-Elect Donald Trump.

[ Learn more ](/us/en/insights/trump-win-policies-market-economy.html "What Trump's win may mean for the markets and economy")

## Transcript

##  US elections and investment implications 

[Andy Blocker](/us/en/our-people/andy-blocker.html), Invesco’s Global Head of Public Policy, joins the InsuranceAUM.com Podcast to discuss the state of the presidential race, the candidates’ regulatory agendas, and what investors need to know during this tumultuous election year. 

00:00

00:00

00:00

Listen

Show transcript

## Transcript : US elections and investment implications

Stewart ([00:02](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/a2xB15BssJDmGFs8tNfwmS8N_1SL2lyze2geYe9CxJn55X8cBpFO5P7y1KAT4ZWLJd83MlkDNgpeCSv7YZ07MzaldOY?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=2.31)): Welcome to another edition of the InsuranceAUM.com podcast. My name's Stewart Foley, I'll be your host. Hey, welcome back and thanks for joining us. We've got a great one for you today. The topic is US elections and investment implications therefrom, and we're joined by Andy Blocker, who's Global Head of Public Policy and Strategic Partnerships at Invesco. Andy, thanks for being on, man. Thanks for taking the time.

Andy ([00:50](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/QIeTp8yFwH7okkvddJ8f6cAdusEh3laMqp4HHGUQtWRHoskRA-jlJ7lj6aPUakIZk7m_xaQs9Dgc5BlNv4pvPrHRN_k?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=50.67)): Great to be with you.

Stewart ([00:51](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/GhjbX9_yt6jwjFEa0u33CWYmJkTQH3buvgcuT0_eWkpP3a4JQqXSoVZpAQvPOFlB3l4xbewWqeO46-RD78KBk9BYpNY?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=51.78)): It's great to be here. You are a veteran of podcasts, and I'm tickled to get to talk with you about this, which is I think on everyone's mind right now. But before we get going too far, where did you grow up, your hometown, and what was your first job? Not the fancy one.

Andy ([01:11](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/Il3zMLq4bt0DrJP1Ftr8c51IgsHnhsG9mAjPhXBZ9cYq1wNSVBT3pLm842XNpme64g_QAORJSwXSIUGDcMcoUb1OC0w?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=71.61)): Look, I get this question all the time, where am I from and it's a tough answer because it's got many parts. So the quick and dirty is, born in Little Rock, Arkansas, packed my bags when I was 2 so I could move close to the big city, New York City, but was in Jersey. So I was in Jersey, Jersey Strong for 11 years of my life. And then for high school, I moved to Maryland, a suburb right between Baltimore and DC, but a little bit closer to DC. So that's that answer.

And my first job was actually a business that I started with my buddy down the street. We lived on Bignonia Drive, so we called it Bignonia Brothers. And it was not a cutting grass situation, it was a landscaping. We did full service.

Stewart ([01:58](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/8NP3bYtX8cpiSG8vJ2Qo1tMxq2g4o6S5IJGczcELaliwRol5zfG-Hus2RP-Aj2xlcgG5rSjgwfiFuqG5qr3rkXADiHo?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=118.38)): Wow.

Andy ([01:58](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/dli_xKrw-EV_5exrHrzO7m6bVj5Ytv6VegC4fbD5Q9SrQMUIEWtx8QUtZzquBid1BvkytIaKz15NcOex0teaS1xZv-M?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=118.47)): We not only cut your grass, we do the trimming of your bushes, and if you wanted some more stuff, we'd do it for you too.

Stewart ([02:04](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/18p3DxwP65kODSTx2XKvUA6SDLkA2fxzYU82bGqQt4CJuZp5zbRAA8smo95oMtZOgZbq9Bozh3_SUoWfiYsZKcp3wsk?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=124.71)): Wow, I love that. I was basically labor for my grandfather starting at about age 8, which was my birthday present, was a riding lawn mower, and it was a full service-

Andy ([02:18](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/drnj7e_b4DyHWNCYgDxleoRZBSsH8njDgga8RXJz-cCgsbSlKFD6buU6WZderHmhRKQ-QtAokbAGNQx54az8DMw1nZ4?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=138.03)): Wait, wait, wait, dude, you're living in style and you got the ride. I'm talking about legit push-pull.

Stewart ([02:27](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/7qCYHybgX1ibRq_uBrAUkMxMtUKqnoxUdRZBEZfJ7gm1P9ELWkVrcbTWJw6t0Fqk27JQQj_ol4ZvYBIZKTtctXnsrbU?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=147.27)): Yeah.

Andy ([02:28](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/F2JM83K7ZfAZSldKGXcbi1L7-R1iC7jmAzAdL4043DI93Qfnz6ccrN6BBJZGO-AeIr0FHvHcGhBjwd2ReLxZ4zNl69Y?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=148.1699999)): It was at least gas. It wasn't like the old school ones.

Stewart ([02:28](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/2wRrKLl3mBBhjMaKV3Xy2YnXR_olg4_FLIoN2LTLqL-BTkrvyyzfZKY6pTiF3bJwGv5Kk-EnsP0wDz15YWfMF7F6BgE?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=148.26)): Yeah, I know.

Andy ([02:28](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/ZMljT0KaNXh8g7csFbFh4RSReowjO1WkisySUsuEKVo9Z127PyI-nwCahHEGgxLoTmqYNIlJU7rRWjOKsc1gvmRLK3Q?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=148.26)): But yeah.

Stewart ([02:32](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/l1pjPMFTMG_l3-EUof-GhErA8MSt_ijPkBARFHisj2J0Kwdtu2aupF0J8_7gPLmkZfVgAd2AuUZwh3OjWsm3wHrQCEM?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=152.55)): We lived on 11 acres and my grandfather wanted it to look like a park all the time. So we did have a push mower, but it was mainly riders. I'll be first to tell you.

You've had some really interesting career experiences prior to Invesco, including the White House, which is I think... I've had the opportunity. I had a really good friend, my college RA, a guy named Tony Wilson, who was actually Al Gore's scheduler at one point, and he actually got us into… I got a tour with him of the White House, which is regardless of your politics, I mean you have to respect the place. I mean, it is amazing. You've seen it your whole life. I was astonished that I was there. So I'd love to know about your career prior to Invesco and how you became the global head of public policy there.

Andy ([03:27](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/VAMCcCmKnSuyqB96zJ_QXRdF5EXw_SfPtBZu7d2ZSd1BBSG2eSLwoPMDwU4qgMpLVGiFz1gn4M70uvlb4VhyNtnpE6g?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=207.12)): So interesting. So my first, not real, real job in high school, but my first job after college was actually at Bell Atlantic; I was a Financial Analyst in a big building, and then I got an opportunity to move over to politics. So I moved over and made a lot less money. I think my starting salary on Capitol Hill was $19,000 a year working as a congressional aide to a congressman from Texas.

And then I moved from there to a senator from Tennessee who was chair of the Budget Committee, and then I ended up at the White House. So there's all kinds of things there. And then after that I got a chance to move to the private sector, worked at American Airlines, doing a bunch of things there, and then switched over to financial services industry at the New York Stock Exchange and have been there ever since. But anyway, so there's more there. But yeah, it's been a pretty varied career here.

Stewart ([04:24](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/6oVu5i_y6mLoup1BgdjKXqeG2-XdrdirgqDXzS4COdBZQPrM3O4GIpCLwF7egCc0WJeNw5duSWxwJe_HSm5AeEsDqAQ?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=264.66)): So it's been a summer of political surprises, and I would say that it's been a few years worth of political surprises. You had Trump and Biden, then you have the fallout of the Biden-Trump debate. There's an assassination attempt. Harris replaces Biden, can you help... And the DNC, the convention is going on right now as at the time of this recording, which is the 21st of August. Can you help unpack some of this and talk about the impact in your mind on the election? And if you want to do a little handicapping, I'm all for it.

Andy ([05:06](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/pgj8oll5UTXsmJ-G9kyuenks_aOYJLCje1rCq8D4epz3rrjYGPw9wgr19Ec5S-WV7LXIFtwJLVMSzRXdsGIy7hRnzPY?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=306.9299999)): Yeah, Stew, you really asked the easy questions here, unpack all of that.

Stewart ([05:10](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/yAmbgXPiU_indwgqPyHpKZ2Htms67ET1oONmjI3ZbHAvfbQgpwL0QCxjdwC-FRVdY2dk2TziQZQUagZgGzyQHKPQFFQ?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=310.62)): Yeah.

Andy ([05:11](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/AfIZHThnlDnKwKr9XdnnUZAIfZVYCoF4TCbhQhtn8yD-9xcs_mNqFjxbGEP8Ius2KnQiLj3QoduQi9dTgXbcz3ywXFk?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=311.19)): This is historic territory. I've never seen in my 30 years of actually working in the political space, a period of 50-odd days like this.

I mean, you unpacked it. If you add it all together, we had 34 felony counts for one of the candidates, followed by a debate debacle by the other candidate, with concomitant internal party revolt. Then followed by assassination attempt, followed by one of the candidates getting out. And then after the candidate got out, we thought it was going to be chaos, and it was coalescence around Kamala Harris, and that's still going on.

So I've been saying for two years, ever since the midterm elections, going around the globe saying, "Get over it. It's going to be Trump V Biden, because they're the ones who make the decision on whether or not they're the standard-bearer for their parties. So unless there's a health incident that I can't predict, that's what's happening." And people can argue about whether the debate was a health incident, it's health related, clearly.

Stewart ([06:21](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/O3pHa-AgP5PVTASM7key5hqgpeUl4hzngoPPQfynWO1770IB8bRYZpK_kWI5ME5iLKu_EErxgotSxw5-9prT20zBh08?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=381.06)): Sure.

Andy ([06:21](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/vGkBzDHjaqGFeJlmXyRUpb9V9JGtx4TVyuiGs_FjMtlcEjECCrLAJ-mOqAcQnmG8o5hq8DyncM6281cRrXYt-RPiGBw?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=381.6)): But it wasn't until one of them decided that they were going to step aside. And I think President Biden was assisted in that decision, but he made the decision. And because any other way you weren't going to... If you kicked him out, whatever situation you thought you were in before was going to get worse. You're going to have a divided party, you're going to have chaos, and you're just ensuring the other party wins.

So to get to that point where they were actually able to convince him to step aside and set the party up for at least a chance going to November, was just amazing. So even if nothing else happened between now and the end, it's already been one of the most amazing election periods that I've seen. And handicapping, I mean, really you want to...

Stewart ([07:06](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/pf09r4XA_1foIXWbilZzbPseZp-qfm0YixF5tR367tsUcNWsLe_ocTnl9SIL7AemzLssl2je76KroM-B3smdW86cypM?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=426.24)): Okay, all right, but let me ask you this. So in what's always the case is that I've got some harebrained opinion and the guest goes, "Well, you know..." So there were people, the chatter that I heard is neither one of these two guys. When it was Trump-Biden people were like, neither one of these two guys, I don't like either one of them. And now it appears that Kamala Harris is benefiting from that, that it's almost like she's late enough to the party that there hasn't been all this focus and negativity on her for all this time. Do you think that she benefits from not being an aging older candidate?

Andy ([07:54](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/qIp0-TW8T3vCpL6wditw24qOQFWk1jL8tp37JTqGX2wQK4LHW1LdrxLpqS9TAvF3kuVMApTd9lcqyod4HUDVlAqu3pc?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=474.24)): Look, I think you've hit on it. I think going back to my talking to clients for the last two years, I was basically telling them, "Hey, go through your five stages of grief. Stop being in denial. Stop getting angry, stop negotiating. This is what it is."

Stewart ([08:09](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/OVdHJz_rAbYvomXezz5Zmwru1KwK_vcEb-dUGmVQsclx1IDY7SawlO_dmOT2SW49vdNjUHD7Nsw954EBwabo9tdAyHo?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=489.84)): Yeah.

Andy ([08:10](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/2BYv1PaP4tk7iPrptgO_bU8_8m7m8Lil7cqLYmpwteF-rXJBc-KUItB794wni4f1a5oCtwGdmZHW9a3yI3WgEM_J3dY?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=490.02)): And I actually went through my five stages of grief, and so I was all settled, but they continued to ask me and I had to start my session with saying, "Michelle Obama is not walking through that door." I would have to start the session off. And she wasn't anyway, because she doesn't want to run for office, which is probably smart on her part.

Stewart ([08:28](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/lN7qB5Lp2T-lSS7VuWnl9XC643NL-hBJFSL1xJ9qVqpi572iBlojEszk4ETCpOQUt7PSNC5SPWx6hYomCBD2OAveEC0?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=508.17)): And she's made that clear, right? I mean, she's made that-

Andy ([08:30](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/0seMSntnsz8sdJEpX85I-Kfq_uYQZXc2XmK_2faiSX9sb8Hk7dO2EpoJMEsfV28GNgSSL4jnpkkqvjQucrYV0p6thPU?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=510.48)): Oh, yeah, she's clear.

Stewart ([08:30](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/ztrtp8SoxEEXsjaXBTYRtaWcImJfZIBsxVvVFmA7WAWgKYjbOZ86MSWfUcwrAtVihFh2cagy6vBMhwhpE6cQxeGFTSg?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=510.51)): ... Abundantly clear.

Andy ([08:30](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/ZHSb1h5Ju5JJfsnKXTt8q4uJS6KVBVLvEoXPI03Wb9agFJ55TpKpCTiWYpfa5Q6Ra3_2Txe0_dbRmoSUAv0vPZVVkmI?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=510.51)): She didn't even want her husband to run.

Stewart ([08:30](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/8MQD1fwPoWmBE931D9geN4Tb2PFk-Guzx2sgdh_j7S2uk-Dxw0HD4e93JgAVkI4gxVnSLhFi_aSIRHBEcV_zLDKu8Pw?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=510.51)): Right.

Andy ([08:36](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/kQUMjBuF4tUyuBH_n0T1yftb3JDUgUNTVB91VPD0nlX5IK57EflqtapGiodZ0WHv3_teBZ9KLSEYfPWEkHdIZ2jM7d0?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=516.03)): So my thing is, what you've hit on is that what I think does explain a lot of this energy for Kamala right now, is that... And I think Nikki Haley had it right even though she's trying to deny it now, when she said the first party to get rid of their 80-year-old candidate is going to win this election. Well, the first party who got rid of their 80-year-old candidate has increased their chances tremendously. And what I think is going on now is that they're being pretty smart about trying to channel all of that anti-energy into positive energy and saying, "Yes, she's the one you've been waiting for," doing a little voodoo spell on them or a little hypnosis.

You know what I saying? Look, I think a lot of this is real, but a lot of it's just like we want anybody, "Oh, you're there and you're 20 years younger, we like you." So I'm not trying to diminish what Kamala's bringing to the table, but I'm also saying it's capturing all of this energy and trying to bottle it in Kamala's favor. And I think Trump sees that, which is why I think he's been a little on edge.

Stewart ([09:44](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/hEA9EOBGCYx3MprUnMpsyHVMFg6OuVDbADc3PK0pdC0Q_AqANZXiyi-ed5C3x3fklOcQTRNHJkbVtXbv2icwzOz5zRk?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=584.16)): And so there's been a couple of things happen. So the Supreme Court made a ruling that essentially said that you can't be prosecuted criminally while you're president if you're doing anything that resembles being president. Does that decision trouble you in any way or is it, did that need to happen?

Andy ([10:10](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/XxGaxHrf9Ju-W1Fu9Tl2zdQrhjpHxoqqhWV8f2GSM7ECHBERvXVXzcRGivFrGvXHZOzVlRQtqC6GhK88oKEBy_Kux0A?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=610.5599999)): There's many ways to look at it. So on the surface, if you're just looking at it broad strokes, it could be construed as the president has immunity if he's doing an official act. And then the question becomes, what's an official act, right?

Stewart ([10:25](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/fUPc7DPuZb5eCndcMsIvCNYNOBCtbl8OE2W7iXcBb4aKIe3eIyoqm_q2-gI2R61KnC-vCTzK95x4Mw9dLQWe_O4rPQ8?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=625.41)): Yeah.

Andy ([10:26](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/qDgeksdPyIE_UbasVIsnjr4g6FQXcyVjArFkhTS5PoVKZgzWiUrUifNmuMaxzn6BFMz0o7Q82vKyzWFEGG1-rtQ_9yk?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=626.13)): What are you... So I think they're going to have to tighten that up over time 'cause what they're trying to prevent... And look, just so you understand, I mean part of the legal theory here is from the conservative side and especially John Roberts who's the Supreme Court Justice, I feel like there are many people who want to preserve the power of the presidency. They don't want to hamstring the president from not taking an action because of potential future litigation.

Okay, I understand intellectually that thought. But if you're going to do that, you need to have some guardrails around it, especially when you're talking about someone like Donald Trump. And the reason I'm focusing on him a little bit is 'cause he's kind of different from a lot of the other actors we've had out there, where others I think have had a little bit more respect for the office than him, and that is what it is. But I don't think you can ever totally account for someone like Donald Trump.

Anyway, that aside, it troubles me in the sense of it's not defined, but I think the future court cases will define what that means, and I think we'll have more comfort there. I mean, you don't want to have it so that he just does XYZ or she does XYZ, then on post-hoc say, "Oh, it was an official act."

So I think you want constraints on... You don't want the president to be seen as above the law when he's acting as president, because that can... It's almost an endless thing. But I would hope that the court, as they bring exacting specific instances, that they will be able to define that more what they mean by that, so that no one's truly above the law.

Stewart ([12:12](https://www.rev.com/transcript-editor/shared/XR_S3Jg_nxm7pU4X9Hxvlwo75KY1JKngyxR8RcI-zV5XPIlNBORrZ_FAG_EufMZ3dIvu-Km-NjoHJwQtYn7uwW6falM?loadFrom=DocumentDeeplink&ts=732.45)): Thank you. There's been a lot of talk about paths to victory, and I would be the first to tell you that I'm not incredibly clear on what exactly that means. I mean, I kind of know, but can you talk a little bit about what people mean when they say path to victory? And then what do you think Trump's path to victory and Harris's path to victory is?
